channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: North Korea Tests a Mightier Nuclear Bomb, Raising Tension
item.media:description: A meeting to celebrate the 68th anniversary of the founding of the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea was held in the capital, Pyongyang, on Friday.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The test, South Korean officials said, produced a more powerful explosive yield than the North’s previous detonations.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: North Korea’s Nuclear Blasts Keep Getting Stronger
item.media:description: Researchers at the Earthquake and Volcano Monitoring Division, in Seoul, the South Korean capital, checking the seismic waves that were measured on Friday.
item.description: The tremors caused by each test have grown larger, and the North appears closer to building a nuclear device small enough to be mounted on a missile.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Hajj Prep: Search Soul, Buy Sturdy Shoes, Pay the Dentist
item.media:description: Pilgrims in Mina, a few miles from Mecca. “I cannot begin to describe the crowds,” Diaa’s brother wrote on the family WhatsApp forum. “You will often be stuck in human traffic moving only by the will of people around you, almost like a wave carrying you.”
item.description: Diaa Hadid, a Times correspondent, is getting ready for her first hajj, the annual pilgrimage to Mecca. And her family and colleagues have plenty of advice.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: What Muslims Do on Hajj, and Why
item.media:description: Muslim worshipers at the Grand Mosque in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, in July last year. The black cube at the center is known as the Kaaba.
item.description: Our correspondent, who is in Saudi Arabia for the annual pilgrimage, explains why Muslims, dressed in white, throw stones, kiss a large black rock and have a goat sacrificed.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: My Hajj Reading List: Preparing for Mecca
item.description: Our correspondent shares her reading list before embarking on the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: The Saturday Profile: From Where Ex-Taliban Minister Sits, Demand Is Growing for Afghan Peace
item.media:description: Sayed Abdul Wasi Motasim, a former Taliban minister, in Kabul recently.
item.media:credit: Robert Nickelsberg for The New York Times
item.description: Agha Jan Motasim, a back-channel negotiator who works in secret after taking 12 bullets, insists that the Taliban are thinking about talks despite recent advances.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: An Afghan Father-Son Tale Takes a Fatal Turn, but Does Not End
item.media:description: Abdul Basir, left, an Afghan government militia fighter, and his son Said Muhammad, a former Taliban militant, after they made peace and before Mr. Basir was killed.
item.description: Abdul Basir and his son Said Muhammad were sworn enemies until they made peace last month, but the story of their fight against the Taliban has been called into question.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ZAHRA NADER

item.title: U.S. Rescue Attempt in Afghanistan Missed Western Hostages by Hours
item.media:description: Darulaman Road in Kabul, Afghanistan, where two professors from the American University of Afghanistan were abducted last month.
item.description: Navy SEALs led the unsuccessful raid to free an American professor and his Australian colleague from the Taliban last month, engaging in a fierce gunfight.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and ADAM GOLDMAN

item.title: 73 Syrian Aid Groups Suspend Cooperation with U.N.
item.media:description: Food aid in Aleppo, Syria. Relief groups say information shared with the United Nations is being misused by Syrian officials.
item.description: The groups said the United Nations had been manipulated by the government so that civilians in opposition-held areas get little or no help.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: ‘What Is Aleppo?’ Gary Johnson Asked. Let Us Explain.
item.description: An American presidential candidate asked what Aleppo is on national television. Some of the basics about what’s going on there.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK

item.title: Mystery Surrounds Car With Gas Containers Found in Paris Near Notre Dame
item.media:description: Forensics investigators inside a building in Boussy-Saint-Antoine on Thursday, where three female suspects, said to have been planning acts of violence in Paris, were arrested.
item.media:credit: Geoffroy Van Der Hasselt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The car did not contain detonators, but the police have arrested four people — all suspected of being Islamist extremists — in connection with the case.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Clubbers Lament Demise of Fabric, a ‘Totem’ of London’s Dance Scene
item.media:description: The closing of Fabric reverberated among clubgoers across the world, for whom a stop at the nightclub was a must-do on any trip to London.
item.description: The deaths of two 18-year-olds in drug-related cases led the authorities to close down one of the capital’s most fabled electronic music venues.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Decoding North Korea’s Claim of a Successful Nuclear Test
item.media:description: Screens at the Korea Meteorological Administration, in Seoul, South Korea, showing seismic waves on Friday. The detonation was equivalent to 10 kilotons of TNT, the Defense Ministry said.
item.description: Correspondents of The New York Times provide context and analysis on the statement issued by North Korea that claimed success for a nuclear test.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Passengers Trapped Overnight in Mont Blanc Cable Cars Are Rescued
item.media:description: Three cable cars that stalled in the French Alps on Thursday.
item.description: All 110 people left hanging 12,500 feet in the Mont Blanc massif near Chamonix, France — including 33 who were stranded until morning — were safely evacuated.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE and MARTIN DE BOURMONT

item.title: Sinosphere: New Push for Taiwan’s Representation at the United Nations
item.media:description: The weight lifter Tan Chi-Chung competed in the Rio Olympics under the banner of “Chinese Taipei,” not Taiwan. A civic group is pushing for Taiwan to be recognized as a country under its own name.
item.description: Michael Tsai of the Taiwan United Nations Alliance discusses efforts to win the island’s full membership in the world body, a notion anathema to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: KAROLINE KAN

item.title: Isabelle Dinoire, Recipient of First Partial Facial Transplant, Dies at 49
item.media:description: Isabelle Dinoire in February 2006. In 2005 she received the world’s first partial facial transplant.
item.description: Her 2005 operation paved the way for dozens of other patients to receive this complicated surgery.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: British Parliament Set to Relocate to Save a Crumbling Palace
item.media:description: Scaffolding at the Palace of Westminster in London. A committee has recommended that both houses of Parliament move to other nearby buildings in 2022.
item.description: A report suggests the House of Commons and House of Lords should move out of the iconic Palace of Westminster in 2022 for nearly four billion pounds worth of repairs and upgrades.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Donald Trump’s Campaign Stands By Embrace of Putin
item.media:description: Mrs. Clinton arrived in Kansas City, M.O., to address the National Baptist Convention on Thursday.
item.description: The signals of preference for the leadership of an adversary over that of the president came despite criticism from Democrats and discomfort among Republicans.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN MARTIN and AMY CHOZICK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Siberia, a ‘Blood River’ in a Dead Zone Twice the Size of Rhode Island
item.media:description: Red sediment along the banks of the Daldykan River in northern Siberia on Thursday.
item.description: The Norilsk Nickel plant is one of the world’s biggest polluters, so it was no surprise when the nearby Daldykan River began to run red.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Perpignan Journal: ‘Don’t Erase Us’: French Catalans Fear Losing More Than a Region’s Name
item.media:description: A flag representing Catalan independence hanging outside a shop in Perpignan, France. In the city, which was once an important military fortress, opponents of the name Occitanie given to an enlarged region are determined to resist.
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.description: Combining the Languedoc-Roussillon and Midi-Pyrénées regions under a new name, Occitanie, is regarded by some as a threat to their cultural identity.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Top Palestinian Court Postpones Oct. 8 Municipal Elections
item.media:description: Palestinian judges discussed suspending municipal elections at the High Court, in the West Bank city of Ramallah, on Thursday.
item.description: The ruling follows a challenge to a decision to exclude balloting in East Jerusalem, but the Fatah-Hamas rivalry is also a factor.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Leaving Asia, Obama Predicts U.S. Tilt Toward Region Will Be Lasting
item.description: The president defended the success of the meetings on his tour and dismissed the distractions that caught the news media’s attention as overblown.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: In Glasgow, a Most Bitter Rivalry Takes Root Again
item.media:description: Rangers fans waving flags in the stands at the Scottish Cup semifinal against Celtic in April at Hampden Park in Glasgow.
item.description: Rangers and Celtic, known as the Old Firm, have not met in a league match in four years, since financial mismanagement led to Rangers’ liquidation.
item.dc:creator: RORY SMITH

item.title: After Mass Knife Attack in Japan, Disabled Victims Are Still in the Shadows
item.media:description: Takashi, left, and Chikiko Ono, with a photo of their son, Kazuya, at their home in Zama, Japan. Kazuya survived a knife attack at a center for mentally disabled people in July.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: The police have withheld the names of the victims, citing relatives’ wishes, which critics say tacitly endorses a view of disabled people as lesser beings.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Taliban Close to Overtaking Afghan Provincial Capital, Officials Say
item.media:description: Security forces on the Kandahar-Helmand highway in Afghanistan on Wednesday.
item.description: The militants were firing on government buildings in the southern city of Tirin Kot, the capital of Oruzgan Province, officials reported.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Sinosphere: Air China Will Fly You to London, and Warn You About Dark-Skinned People There
item.media:description: An article in a recent issue of Wings of China, an Air China in-flight magazine, has drawn criticism as being racist.
item.description: A recent in-flight magazine article said, “Precautions are needed when entering areas mainly populated by Indians, Pakistanis and black people.”
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: What in the World: Something Old, Something New, Something Borrowed, Something Hindu
item.description: A traditional Indian wedding can last days, and rituals include the bride kicking over a pot of rice and dance competitions between Team Bride and Team Groom.
item.dc:creator: AMISHA PADNANI

item.title: What in the World: Whether Shaved by Hand or Machine, This Roman Treat Is Just as Frosty
item.description: Purveyors of grattachecca, the traditional homegrown version of a snow cone, have spirited debates about the proper way to prepare the ice.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Opinion: The Flavors That Unite Syrians
item.description: Food is what defines the people of Syria, even after years of war and displacement.
item.dc:creator: DALIA MORTADA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Editorial: Crisis in Calais
item.description: Britain and France, two of the wealthiest countries in Europe, have failed to deal humanely with more than 10,000 people stuck in a migrant tent camp.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Angela Merkel’s Loyalty Test for German Turks
item.media:description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan at a bilateral meeting within the framework of the G20 Summit in Hangzhou, China, last week.
item.media:credit: Jseco Denzel, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Should the chancellor be questioning their patriotism? Millions of Germans think so.
item.dc:creator: ANNA SAUERBREY

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Readers React: Seeing Orange: What Caught Commenters’ Eyes About a Small Syrian Boy in a Big Chair
item.media:description: Omran Daqneesh, 5, was rescued after an airstrike in the Syrian city of Aleppo.
item.description: Our Photo Editors’ Notebook on what made the image of Omran Daqneesh stand out inspired many readers to share their thoughts.
item.dc:creator: INSIDER STAFF
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
